走路引起了伏案的人的兴趣。我们把它浪漫化，但我们做得公平吗？我们走路正常吗？一个人可以不正确地行走吗？如果可以，当行走被纠正时会发生什么？
行走可以移动或安顿思维 - ，从而实现自我发现。“我只有在走路的时候才能冥想，”让-雅克·卢梭(Jean-Jacques Rousseau)说。亚里士多德被认为是一位巡回讲师。当时的法国人用弗洛内尔来框定这位文学漫步者。史蒂夫·乔布斯(Steve Jobs)在旧帕洛阿尔托(Old Palo Alto)的街道上进行了深入的交谈。众所周知，摩西与几个朋友分开了一整片海去散步。
走得好和走得好是有艺术和历史的。托马斯·克拉克(Thomas Clark)在赞颂步行的诗中写道：“在晴朗的夜晚步行数小时是我们所能拥有的最大体验。”他说的是星空下的乡村漫步。但是，在城市中夜行也带来了它自己的巨大乐趣。丽贝卡·索尔尼特(Rebecca Solnit)在“漫游欲望”(Wanderlust)中写道，“城市总是提供匿名、多样性和关联性，这些品质最好是通过散步来享受。”
神秘的事物呈现给步行者 - 上方漂浮的吉他声，纱门的低语，猫被冻住了，浴缸溅起水花，远处摩托车的嗡嗡声。谜团有时会起到作用，更多的时候只是作为步行者心灵飞逝的叙述的压舱物。
然而，对于大多数城市来说，能够安全地独自行走，特别是在夜间，在很大程度上是一种只有男性才能享受的奢侈品(即使这样，也总是有一些地方需要避免)。这就是为什么东京的夜行特别诱人和令人回味，似乎是一个社会奇迹 - 一个几乎没有暴力犯罪的城市，几乎没有后巷或光线昏暗的小路是禁区。这是少数几个真正的大都市空间之一，在那里，安全步行的权利几乎是普遍的、不分青红皂白的，无论白天还是黑夜，红灯或金融区都是一样的。
林恩·蒂尔曼(Lynne Tillman)作品中的主人公伊丽莎白(Elizabeth)将步行限制在曼哈顿东村的几个街区内。尽管如此，这并不能阻止她在脑海中旅行，小细节绽放成全景：
伊丽莎白打开门走下楼梯。大厅在半夜里更加黯淡。黎明时分。农民们每天早上都是这样醒来的，清晨挤牛奶，在炎热或寒冷中四处晃动，喂比他们聪明的猪，长得皱巴巴的，饱经风霜，他们的妻子做令人心碎的早餐，在阳光下枯萎，哺育好斗的幼崽，或者死于分娩。每个人都是英雄。伊丽莎白咯咯地笑了起来，然后抑制住了自己。
皮科·艾尔因为在京都漫步而爱上了整个国家。“我最喜欢的京都漫步始于一座半隐蔽的寺庙，叫做格申寺(Gesshin-in)，”他以局内人的身份带我们若有所思地游览了这座城市。艾尔教我们要注意。注意到这是一个好的步行者的核心属性之一。走路再简单也不能不注意。最好的步行者养成了一种习惯，那就是他们会如此坚定地注意到自己的存在，以至于他们不由自主地注意到了。需要帮忙注意吗？把一架旧相机吊在肩上。(这不是关于捕捉，而是透过磨砂玻璃看。)
行走的伟大是长度的不确定。一次伟大的散步可以是长的，也可以是短的。我也在京都偶然发现了一次散步，虽然不是在市区，也没有艾尔散步的时间长。几年前，我发现了杜鲁门·卡波特(Truman Capote)在“纽约客”(New York Ker)上对马龙·白兰度(Marlon Brando)的简介。他在京都采访了他。我决定追查他们的下落。我的散步发生在一家老旅馆，他们聊天的地点。步行的时间很短，只有几分钟，追赶着白兰度和卡波特的鬼魂，沿着宫古宫铺着柔软地毯的过道走下去：
我蜿蜒穿过四楼迷宫般的走廊。它向四面八方伸展。我粗鲁而严厉地向走廊里走在我对面的工作人员点头，试图让人觉得我知道自己要去哪里，就像我属于那里一样。
最后，我找到了一间可能是白兰度的房间。它是不是，无关紧要。重点是这场小小的冒险，在漫游中想知道白兰度和卡波特是否在我走过的同一个空间里吃着苹果派，我们脚步的同步性只被时间的折叠所隔开。从短短的散步中剔除的大神话。
凌晨两点，…。歌舞厅都关门了，只有猫陪着我，还有醉汉和闯红灯的女士，不可避免的在门口乞讨的老乞丐，还有一个衣衫褴褛的街头音乐家，他跟着我吹着中世纪的长笛。我跋涉了一英里多，最后，百条小巷中的一条通向熟悉的Ground - ，那是由百货商店和电影院组成的主街地区。就在那时，我看到了白兰度。六十英尺高，他的头和最伟大的佛陀一样大，他穿着漫画纸的颜色，站在剧院上方的牌子上，上面宣传着“八月之月的茶馆”。
所有的步行者都应该为快乐而努力，所有有价值的步行都是有意或无意地设计来引起快乐的。对意想不到的事情和经常被忽视或考虑不足的事情感到高兴。对若隐若现的马龙·白兰度感到高兴，突然低头盯着你看。
虽然短距离散步可以使停滞不前的头脑活跃或移动，但长距离步行可以滋养和恢复活力。
我是长距离(或中等距离)步行艺术的新手。几年前，我曾徒步旅行到安纳普尔纳·巴塞坎普(Annapurna Basecamp)，但我第一次真正的“散步”是去年和多产的步行者约翰·麦克布莱德(John McBride)一起进行的。几十年来，约翰一直在日本(以及其他国家、沙漠、朝圣)游历。他在十几岁时开始散步时说，他找到了一个新国家的控制权：
散步成为我与日本互动的方式，在不同的文化背景下变得脆弱，但以我自己的方式，并在不同的情况下尽可能多地会见日本人。我开始渴望下一次大学假期，当我可以再次上路的时候，我把我学习的每一个琶句都看作是我最终将走过的世界的一幅图画。
我们三个和另一位朋友一起游览了熊野古道的大片区域，这是一条古老的朝圣小径，最近被联合国教科文组织列为世界遗产。就是在这次散步中，我发现了好伙伴带来的愉悦。一年后，我仍然在拆解、重建和解构我们历史上聚焦的、往往是荒谬的对话。
清醒的散步伙伴将平庸的走路提升到崇高的境界。但是，学习只带着自己走很远的路有自发的优势，为一种自我精神分析打开了闸门。
特朱·科尔(Teju Cole)的“开放城市”(Open City)是一本关于纵向漫游曼哈顿大部分地区和布鲁塞尔零星地区的书。步道从短到长不等，但它们较少以离散的形式存在，更多的是作为更大的聚合弧线的一部分。总而言之，这本书本身就是与主人公朱利叶斯走了很长一段路。
朱利叶斯既是一个非常引人注目的人，也是一个愿意感到高兴(或厌恶)的人。他开始说：“在一个大雨的下午，银杏叶堆在人行道上，齐踝深，看起来就像成千上万个刚从天上掉下来的黄色小生物，我出去散步了。”然后，关于雨及其影响：“雨的强度模糊了我的视线，这是我以前只在暴风雪中注意到的现象，一场暴风雪抹去了最明显的时代迹象，让人无法猜测这是哪个世纪。”
在所有当代作家中，W.G.Sebald的开创性著作“土星环”作为一本关于文学行走的书具有决定性的地位。科尔的工作吸引了许多人，土星开始写道：“1992年8月，当三伏天接近尾声时，我出发去萨福克郡散步，希望能驱散每当我完成一段长时间的工作时笼罩在我身上的空虚。”
“文学的伟大还有可能吗？”苏珊·桑塔格问道。“英语读者能得到的答案为数不多，其中之一就是W.G.Sebald的作品。”W.G.Sebald已经用自己的名声一步一步地押上了赌注。
在购买了一台FitBit后不久，大卫·塞达里斯(David Sedaris)的清醒和行走生活就开始被计步数所主导。
note_en:
Walking intrigues the deskbound. We romanticize it, but do we do it justice? Do we walk properly? Can one walk improperly and, if so, what happens when the walk is corrected?
 Walking moves or settles the mind — allowing for self discovery. “I can only meditate when I’m walking,” said Jean-Jacques Rousseau. Aristotle is well cited as a  peripatetic lecturer. The French contemporarily frame the literary walker with   flâneur. Steve Jobs tore up the streets of Old Palo Alto in deep conversation. Moses famously parted an entire sea to take a walk with a few friends.
  There is an art and history to walking and walking well.  “To walk for hours on a clear night is the largest experience we can have” writes Thomas Clark in his poem,  In Praise of Walking. He was speaking of countryside walks beneath the stars. But a night walk in a city also brings with it its own great pleasures. Rebecca Solnit writes in  Wanderlust,  “Cities have always offered anonymity, variety, and conjunction, qualities best basked in by walking.”
 Mysteries are presented to the walker — the floating sound of a guitar above, screen door murmurs, cats frozen, baths splashing, the far off buzz of a motorcycle. Mysteries sometimes answered, more often serving only as ballast for the flitting narratives of the walker mind.
 Yet the ability to safely walk alone, especially at night, is, for most cities, largely  a luxury available only to men (and even then, there are always parts to be avoided). Which is why Tokyo night walks are especially alluring and evocative, seemingly a societal miracle — a city nearly devoid of violent crime, almost no back alley or poorly lit path is off limits. It’s one of the few, true, metropolitan spaces where the right to a safe walk is a nearly universal, indiscriminate, day or night, red light or financial district alike.
  Elizabeth, the protagonist in Lynne Tillman’s  limits her walks to a few blocks in the East Village of Manhattan. Still, that doesn’t keep her from traveling in the mind, small details blossoming into panoramas:
 Elizabeth opened her door and walked down the stairs. The halls were even bleaker in the middle of the night. Dawn. Farmers woke like this every morning, at the break of day, milked cows, sloshed around in the heat or cold, fed pigs who were more intelligent than they were, grew wrinkled and weather-beaten, and their wives cooked heartbreaking breakfasts, shriveled under the sun, nursed belligerent youngsters or died in childbirth. Everyone’s a hero. Elizabeth giggled then stifled herself.
  Pico Iyer fell in love with an entire country because of  a walk through Kyoto.  “My favourite Kyoto walk begins at a half-hidden temple called Gesshin-in,” he begins, taking us contemplatively through the city as an insider. Iyer teaches us to notice. Noticing being one of the core attributes of a good walker. No walk is too simple on which to not notice. The best walkers build the habit of noticing so firmly into their being that they can’t help it. Need help noticing? Sling an old camera over your shoulder. (It’s not about the capturing but the looking through the ground glass.)
  Walk greatness is indeterminate of length. A great walk can be long or short. I, too, stumbled upon a walk in Kyoto, though not in the city proper, nor as long as Iyer’s. Years ago I found Truman Capote’s  New Yorker profile of Marlon Brando. He interviewed him in Kyoto. I decided to track them down. My walk took place in an old hotel, the location of their chat. The walk was very short, just a few minutes, chasing the ghosts of Brando and Capote down the softly carpeted passages of the Miyako:
 I wound my way through the labyrinthine corridors of the fourth floor. It sprawled in all directions. I nodded curtly and sternly to staff walking opposite me in the hallway, tried to look like I knew where I was going, like I belonged there.
 In the end  I found a room that could have been Brando’s. Whether it was or wasn’t was beside the point. The point was the tiny adventure, the wondering through wandering if Brando and Capote had comported themselves over apple pie in the same space through which I moved, the synchronicity of our footsteps separated only by the folding of time. Big myths culled from short walks.
  At two in the morning … the cabarets are shuttered; only cats remained to keep me company, and drunks and red-light ladies, the inevitable old beggar-bundles in doorways, and, briefly, a ragged street musician who followed me playing on a flute a medieval music. I had trudged far more than a mile when, at last, one of a hundred alleys led to familiar ground — the main-street district of department stores and cinemas. It was then that I saw Brando. Sixty feet tall, with a head as huge as the greatest Buddha’s, there he was, in comic-paper colors, on a sign above a theatre that advertised “The Teahouse of the August Moon.”
  All walkers should strive for delight, all worthy walks designed intentionally or unintentionally to elicit delight. Delight in the unexpected and in things often overlooked or under considered. Delight in looming Marlon Brandos suddenly staring you down.
  While short walks can invigorate or move a stagnant mind, long walks nourish and regenerate.
 I am a newcomer to the art of long (or medium-long) walking. I had  hiked up to Annapurna Basecamp years ago, but the first real “walk walk” I went on was last year with the prolific walker  John McBride. John has been walking Japan (as well as other countries, deserts, pilgrimages) for decades. He remarks on his first few walks as a teenager finding his grip on a new country:
 The walks became my way of interacting with Japan, becoming vulnerable in a different cultural context, but on my own terms, and meeting as many Japanese in different situations as possible. I began to long for the next university break when I could get out on the road again, and saw every Haiku I studied as a picture on the world I would eventually walk through.
 Together, with another friend, the three of us covered large swaths of the  Kumano Kodo, an ancient pilgrimage path, recently made UNESCO World Heritage Site. It was on this walk I discovered the delight of great companions. A year later, still, I am unraveling, reconstructing, and deconstructing our historically focused and often ridiculous conversations.
  Lucid walking partners elevate a banal walk to the sublime. But learning to walk long with only yourself has the advantage of spontaneity, opening the floodgates for a kind of self psychoanalysis.
 Teju Cole’s   Open City is a book of solitudinal wandering through much of Manhattan and snippets of Brussels. The walks range from short to longer, but they exist less in discrete pieces, and more as parts of a larger aggregated arc. Taken together, the book itself is one long walk with the protagonist Julius.
 Julius is both a great noticer and someone willing to be delighted (or disgusted).  “On an afternoon of heavy rain when the ginko leaves were piled ankle-deep across the sidewalk looking like thousands of little yellow creatures freshly fallen from the sky, I went out walking,” he begins. And then, on the rain and its effect:  “The intensity of the rain blurred my sight, a phenomenon I had noticed before only with snowstorms, when a blizzard erased the most obvious signs of the times, leaving one unable to guess which century it was.”
 Of all contemporary writers, W. G. Sebald’s seminal   Rings of Saturn holds a defining position as a book of literary walking. Cole’s work draws many  Saturn begins,  “In August 1992, when the dog days were drawing to an end, I set off to walk the county of Suffolk, in the hope of dispelling the emptiness that takes hold of me whenever I have completed a long stint of work.”
 “Is literary greatness still possible?”  asks Susan Sontag. “One of the few answers available to English-language readers is the work of W. G. Sebald.” W. G. Sebald has staked his fame in steps.
   Soon after purchasing a FitBit, David Sedaris’ waking and walking life became  dominated by step count.

伦敦大学学院研究人员的一项研究描述了43例新冠肺炎患者，他们要么患有暂时性脑功能障碍，要么中风，要么神经受损，要么其他严重的脑影响。
这项研究增加了最近的研究，这些研究也发现这种疾病会损害大脑。
伦敦大学学院神经学研究所的迈克尔·赞迪(Michael Zandi)是这项研究的共同负责人，他说：“我们是否会看到与这场大流行有关的大规模脑损伤--或许类似于1918年流感大流行后20世纪20年代和30年代爆发的昏睡性脑炎--还有待观察。”他来自伦敦大学学院神经病学研究所(Institute Of Neuroology)。
由新型冠状病毒引起的疾病新冠肺炎在很大程度上是一种影响肺部的呼吸系统疾病，但神经科学家和专科脑科医生表示，越来越多的证据表明其对大脑的影响令人担忧。
“我担心的是，我们现在有数以百万计的人和新冠肺炎在一起。如果在一年内我们有1,000万康复的人，而这些人有认知缺陷…。这将影响他们的工作能力和日常生活活动的能力，“加拿大西部大学的神经学家Adrian Owen在接受路透社采访时说。
在《大脑》杂志上发表的这项UCL研究中，9名脑部发炎的患者被诊断出患有一种名为急性播散性脑脊髓炎(ADEM)的罕见疾病，这种疾病更多见于儿童，可由病毒感染引发。
该研究小组表示，通常情况下，他们在伦敦的专科诊所每月会看到大约一名患有ADEM的成年患者，但在研究期间，这一数字已经上升到每周至少一名，他们称这是“令人担忧的增加”。
“考虑到这种疾病只存在了几个月，我们可能还不知道新冠肺炎可能会造成什么长期损害，”该研究的共同负责人罗斯·帕特森(Ross Paterson)说。“医生需要意识到可能的神经影响，因为早期诊断可以改善患者的预后。”
欧文说，新出现的证据强调了需要进行大规模、详细的研究和全球数据收集，以评估这种神经和精神并发症有多常见。
他在covidbrainStudy.com上运营着一个国际研究项目，患者可以报名完成一系列认知测试，看看自从接受新冠肺炎治疗后，他们的大脑功能是否发生了变化。
“这种疾病影响了大量的人，”欧文说。“这就是为什么现在收集这些信息是如此重要的原因。”

LONDON — Scientists warned on Wednesday of a potential wave of coronavirus-related brain damage as new evidence suggested COVID-19 can lead to severe neurological complications, including inflammation, psychosis and delirium.
 A study by researchers at University College London (UCL) described 43 cases of patients with COVID-19 who suffered either temporary brain dysfunction, strokes, nerve damage or other serious brain effects.
  The research adds to recent studies which also found the disease can damage the brain.
 “Whether we will see an epidemic on a large scale of brain damage linked to the pandemic – perhaps similar to the encephalitis lethargica outbreak in the 1920s and 1930s after the 1918 influenza pandemic – remains to be seen,” said Michael Zandi, from UCL’s Institute of Neurology, who co-led the study.
  COVID-19, the disease caused by the new coronavirus, is largely a respiratory illness that affects the lungs, but neuroscientists and specialist brain doctors say emerging evidence of its impact on the brain is concerning.
  “My worry is that we have millions of people with COVID-19 now. And if in a year’s time we have 10 million recovered people, and those people have cognitive deficits … then that’s going to affect their ability to work and their ability to go about activities of daily living,” Adrian Owen, a neuroscientist at Western University in Canada, told Reuters in an interview.
 In the UCL study, published in the journal Brain, nine patients who had brain inflammation were diagnosed with a rare condition called acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (ADEM) which is more usually seen in children and can be triggered by viral infections.
  The team said it would normally see about one adult patient with ADEM per month at their specialist London clinic, but this had risen to at least one a week during the study period, something they described as “a concerning increase.”
  “Given that the disease has only been around for a matter of months, we might not yet know what long-term damage COVID-19 can cause,” said Ross Paterson, who co-led the study. “Doctors need to be aware of possible neurological effects, as early diagnosis can improve patient outcomes.”
 Owen said the emerging evidence underlined the need for large, detailed studies and global data collection to assess how common such neurological and psychiatric complications were.
 He is running an international research project at  covidbrainstudy.com where patients can sign up to complete a series of cognitive tests to see whether their brain functions have altered since getting COVID-19.
 “This disease is affecting an enormous number of people,” Owen said. “That’s why it’s so important to collect this information now.”

为了更好地了解衰老和各种神经疾病背后的秘密，耶鲁医学院的科学家们开始了一项研究，以研究濒临死亡的神经元和中枢神经系统中负责清除死亡细胞和相关碎片的神经胶质细胞之间的复杂相互作用。
一个普通的人体由数百亿个细胞组成，所有这些细胞都经历了一个自然的死亡过程。然而，更重要的是这些死亡细胞从系统中清除的过程。有史以来第一次，研究人员能够想象大脑中濒临死亡的神经元所产生的生物废物的处置情况。
有效地清除死亡细胞是必要的，以防止死亡细胞的积聚，因为死亡细胞会损害神经系统并导致退行性疾病。尽管这种“身体清除”的过程每天都在进行，但在大脑的生长和发育过程中，观察这一过程的工具有限一直是最大的挑战-主要是因为细胞死亡的时间和地点是不可预测的。
“据推测，如果细胞正在死亡，而没有有效地清除它们，碎片可能会造成进一步的损伤和炎症…。如果我们能有效地去除死亡细胞，我们能防止与年龄相关的神经退化吗？“。
利用一种名为“2Phtal”的新技术，研究人员能够使用创新的光化学和病毒方法诱导活着的小鼠单个脑细胞死亡，然后用荧光标记的细胞清理死亡细胞的烂摊子(上图视频)。
这项研究揭示了三种类型的细胞协同工作来完成这项任务-小胶质细胞、星形胶质细胞和NG2细胞各自执行不同的功能。这三种细胞都是神经胶质细胞，包围并支持神经元。
小胶质细胞覆盖死亡细胞的身体以将其清除，而星形胶质细胞则根据需要通过NG2细胞来清理连接的树突。研究人员还观察到，胶质细胞至少需要两倍的时间才能清除老化大脑中死亡细胞的碎片。这不是因为老化的胶质细胞感觉到了垂死的细胞。
这一理解可能对神经退化和大脑功能衰退有重要影响。完整的研究发表在“科学进展”杂志上。

Using a new system they call “2Phatal”, scientists were able to capture the video of a dying brain & the mess being cleaned up
  In an effort to better understand the secrets behind aging and various neurological disorders, scientists at the Yale School of Medicine embarked on a  research to study the complex interactions between dying neurons and the glial cells in the central nervous system that are responsible for clearing dead cells and related debris from the brain.
 An average human body consists of tens of billions of cells and all of them undergo a natural process of dying. Even more important, though, is the process by which these deceased cells are cleaned up from the system. For the first time ever, researchers were able to image the disposal of the biological waste created by dying neurons in the brain.
 Efficient removal of dead cells is necessary to prevent a build-up of dead cells that can damage the nervous system and cause degenerative diseases. Although this process of “corpse removal” takes place on a daily basis, during the growth & development of a brain, the availability of limited tools to observe this has been the biggest challenge — primarily because the timing and location of cell death are unpredictable.
   “Presumably, if cells are dying and there is inefficient removal of them, the debris could be causing further damage and inflammation… And if we can remove dying cells efficiently, can we prevent age-related neurodegeneration?”
  Utilizing a new technique dubbed as “ 2Phatal”, researchers were able to use innovative photochemical and viral methods to induce death in single brain cells in living mice, followed by fluorescent-marked cells cleaning up the mess of the dead cells (video above).
 The study revealed three types of cells worked together in coordination to accomplish the task — with each of the microglia, astrocytes, and NG2 cells performing a different function. All these three are glial cells, which surround and support neurons.
 Microglia cover the body of the dead cell to clean it away, while astrocytes cleaned up the connecting dendrites with NG2 cells chipping in as needed. Researchers also observed that glial cells took at least twice as long to clean away the debris of the dead cells in the aged brain. This is was not because of the aged glia to sense the dying cell.
 This understanding could have important implications for neurodegeneration and the functional decline of the brain. Complete Research was  published in the Journal  Science Advances.
